title: SAM MATTERFACE: Ronald Koeman is a winner - Southampton didn't match his aspirations
text:
Ronald Koeman walked out on Southampton to join Everton (Photo: Gareth Copley) Share Get football   Could   
“Why on earth would Ronald Koeman leave Southampton for Everton?” 
It was a question mooted in the summer, and it’s an answer that is becoming clearer as the season unfolds. 
Southampton aren’t winners, and Ronald Koeman is a winner. 
Maybe not in the short term, with an Everton team that needs investment and restructuring, but he was always going to be on the look out for a club with aspirations and aims that match his own. 
Southampton do not. 
This week will define their season. They face Liverpool in the EFL Cup semi finals at home. Jack Stephens looks dejected after the defeat to Everton earlier this month (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
You might expect for Jurgen Klopp to be a bit apprehensive. Liverpool have just fudged a cup tie, and Mane is on international duty. You might expect a rousing atmosphere in that first leg. It’s a semi final and Wembley is the prize! 
You might have got it as well. If it was at the Dell. 
Not at St Mary’s. Southampton have already shown that twice this season in the Europa League. 
I was astonished by the quietness of the occasion against Inter Milan. It’s Inter Milan! Three European Cups, 18 Series A titles, the team of Zanetti, Figo, Vieri, Bergomi and Ibrahimovic. Read More Southampton lining up Liverpool defender to replace wantaway Jose Fonte Claude Puel replaced Koeman at the helm (Photo: Michael Regan) 
It was the same against Hapoel Be’er Sheva. Southampton had a chance to qualify and they were tactically outmanoeuvred by the Israeli Champions. It was a game of chess, played in an atmosphere to match. 
From the botched PA that couldn’t whip up a bowl of cream, to the ridiculous team selections that put Claude Puel and his side in a position where it went to the last game. It was a mess and it was a wasted opportunity. 
Saints fans won’t like me saying it, but when Portsmouth played AC Milan in the same competition, everyone knew about it. I doubt anyone knows how dramatic Southampton’s exit was. 
Southampton are a “good” club. They develop a regular amount of exciting, British youngsters and they play possession based football. Nathan Redmond looks down in the dumps after their Europa League exit (Photo: Michael Steele) 
It’s not like the days of Le Tissier, Benali and Mark Dennis though. There was devilry and magic then. Whenever I go at Southampton now it feels like a place where everyone wants to be somewhere else. 
The owner wants to sell. The manager’s never last long. The captain wants to leave. The best central defender is happy to whack on a Manchester City shirt. For every true supporter in the crowd, there appears to be someone else they have dragged along who spends most of the night on Instagram. 
I think it’s incredible a club of that size has already thrown away the gift of European football this season, and no one seemed to care. 
Is this what is acceptable there? Will it be ok just that Southampton have reached a semi final of a domestic trophy rather than achieve something they have only ever managed once in their history, and win one? Koeman is eyeing a reunion with Southampton's Virgil van Dijk (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
Will it feel like another successful season, if they just about qualify for Europe or not, but have wads in the bank from the sale of Virgil Van Dijk ? Surely the fans can’t be having that. 
Its easy, when the praise for developing a battery of talent is flowing, and the money from yet another big money transfer is rolling in, to forget what your primary job is. 
It’s to win football matches and trophies, and break new ground. It’s about ambition, and Southampton don't have ambition, and they don’t win trophies. 
They have to change that, and this is their chance. Otherwise, everyone else, just like Ronald Koeman, will give up and leave. poll loading Was Ronald Koeman right to quit Southampton for Everton? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
